| Italian | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | così | | | | di | | | | ponte | | | | in | | | | ponte | | | | altro | | | | parlare | | | | che | | | | la | | | | mio | | | | commedia | | | | cantare | | | | non | | | | curare | | | | venire | | | | e | | | | tenere | | | | il | | | | colmo | | | | quando | | |
query.result:
| Italian | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | così | Latin | ecce + sic | | di | Latin | de | | ponte | Latin | pons, pontis | | in | Latin | in | | ponte | Latin | pons, pontis | | altro | Latin | alter | | parlare | Latin | parabolare | | che | Latin | quod | | la | Latin | illa | | mio | Latin | meus | | commedia | Greek | κωμῳδία (kōmōidía) | | cantare | Latin | cantare | | non | Latin | non | | curare | Latin | curare | | venire | Latin | venire | | e | Latin | et | | tenere | Latin | tenere | | il | Latin | ille | | colmo | Latin | culmen | | quando | Latin | quando |
**Note:**
* The etymology of "ponte" is uncertain, but it may be derived from the Proto-Indo-European root *pont-*, meaning "path" or "crossing". * The etymology of "altro" is also uncertain, but it may be derived from the Proto-Indo-European root *al-*, meaning "other". * The etymology of "parlare" is from the Latin verb "parabolare", which means "to speak". * The etymology of "la" is from the Latin demonstrative pronoun "illa", which means "that". * The etymology of "mio" is from the Latin possessive adjective "meus", which means "my". * The etymology of "commedia" is from the Greek word "κωμῳδία" (kōmōidía), which means "comedy". * The etymology of "cantare" is from the Latin verb "cantare", which means "to sing". * The etymology of "non" is from the Latin negative particle "non", which means "not". * The etymology of "curare" is from the Latin verb "curare", which means "to care for" or "to heal". * The etymology of "venire" is from the Latin verb "venire", which means "to come". * The etymology of "e" is from the Latin conjunction "et", which means "and". * The etymology of "tenere" is from the Latin verb "tenere", which means "to hold" or "to keep". * The etymology of "il" is from the Latin demonstrative pronoun "ille", which means "that". * The etymology of "colmo" is from the Latin noun "culmen", which means "summit" or "peak". * The etymology of "quando" is from the Latin interrogative and relative pronoun "quando", which means "when".
